title: MSP Guidelines
text:
Comprehensive guidelines for implementing Local Marine Spatial Planning in Tanzania and the WIO region.



Community-Centered - Local communities are central to planning and decision-making
Evidence-Based - Decisions grounded in data and scientific research
Inclusive - All stakeholder groups have a voice
Adaptive - Plans can evolve based on new information and changing conditions
Transparent - Open communication and accessible information





Scoping & Stakeholder Engagement - Define planning boundaries and identify key players
Baseline Analysis - Map existing uses, resources, and priorities
Visioning & Goal Setting - Articulate community aspirations
Spatial Planning - Allocate zones for different uses
Implementation - Activate management measures
Monitoring & Review - Track progress and adapt as needed





Step-by-step MSP implementation toolkit
Community engagement templates
Data collection protocols
Monitoring frameworks





Fisheries and food security
Marine conservation and biodiversity
Blue economy development
Climate adaptation and resilience
Conflict resolution in marine planning


Need capacity building? Contact us about training and technical support opportunities.

title: Marine Spatial Planning Project - Scope of Work and Deliverables
text: Location: Mkoani (Pemba) and Mkuranga (Pwani Region), Tanzania

title: Marine Spatial Planning Project - Scope of Work and Deliverables
text: Location: Mkoani (Pemba) and Mkuranga (Pwani Region), Tanzania

title: Marine Spatial Planning Project - Scope of Work and Deliverables
text:
Project Overview
This Marine Spatial Planning project aims to develop comprehensive spatial plans for sustainable coastal and marine resource management in Mkoani and Mkuranga districts. The initiative integrates scientific research, stakeholder engagement, and participatory planning to support evidence-based marine governance and blue economy development.



Collaborative Marine Spatial Planning: Stakeholders and community leaders engage in participatory discussions to shape sustainable management strategies for coastal Tanzania

title: Marine Spatial Planning Project - Scope of Work and Deliverables
text:
Scope of Work and Deliverables

1. Inception Report
Target Completion Date: 15 September 2025
Objectives: Establish project foundations, clarify roles and responsibilities, and align stakeholders on project goals and implementation approach.


Deliverable: A detailed inception report including:

Comprehensive project methodology and approach
Detailed activity schedule and timeline
Data requirements and collection protocols
Stakeholder engagement and consultation plan
Institutional coordination framework













2. Biodiversity Assessment and Trend Analysis
Target Completion Date: 25 January 2026
Lead: Siajali Pamba under guidance of Masumbuko Semba
Objectives: Establish baseline biodiversity conditions and identify temporal trends to inform conservation priorities.
Deliverable: A report on data collection, detailed maps and ground truthing, showing:



Decadal trends in biodiversity loss and gain across Tanzania (focusing on mangrove ecosystems)
Regional context and significance for marine conservation
Spatial distribution maps of key biodiversity indicators
Ground-truthed field observations and validation data
High-resolution geospatial mapping of mangrove loss/gain trends for coastal districts
Restoration priority areas for carbon offset schemes and climate mitigation













3. Field Data Collection and Mapping
Target Completion Date: 25 January 2026
Lead: Masumbuko Semba with guidance from Siajali Pamba
Objectives: Collect primary data across multiple disciplines and develop spatial datasets to support planning decisions.
Deliverable: Comprehensive field data collection and map layer development:



Physical data: Bathymetry, coastal morphology, oceanographic parameters, seabed morphology, ocean currents, sea level trends, salinity, temperature, acidification, upwelling zones
Biological data: Fish populations, coral reef conditions, seagrass beds, biodiversity hotspots, mangroves, critical fish habitats, migratory corridors (turtles, sharks)
Geomorphological data: Habitat classifications, erosion zones, ecosystem boundaries
Socioeconomic data: Fisher demographics, livelihood patterns, resource use intensity, settlements, infrastructure, tourism hubs
Marine resource use data: Fishing effort distribution, gear types, seasonal patterns, aquaculture/mariculture zones, fish landing sites, CFMAs, CMAs, BMUs  










Data Sources: ESA data (10m resolution), NAFORMA, TAN-Sea map, ECAS data, TPDC (oil and gas), open street maps, Frame survey data



4. Ecosystem Services Valuation
Target Completion Date: 31 March 2026
Lead: Gervas Maro with assistance from Julius Francis
Objectives: Quantify the economic value of marine ecosystems to support conservation and sustainable use arguments.
Deliverable: A comprehensive economic valuation report including:



Baseline valuation of coastal and marine ecosystem goods and services in USD
Spatial mapping of classified ecosystem assets and service categories
Classification and cataloging of coastal and marine assets with focus on key habitats (mangroves, coral, seagrasses, beaches)
Ecosystem services analysis through comparative risk analysis:

Provisioning services (food provisioning from marine fish catch, mariculture, agriculture, raw materials, fuelwood, timber)
Regulating/supporting services (carbon sequestration, habitat maintenance, regulation of extreme events)
Cultural services (tourism, recreation, ecotourism)















5. Bio-Economic Cost-Benefit Analysis
Target Completion Date: 31 March 2026
Lead: Emmanuel Mpina with inputs from project team members
Objectives: Demonstrate the economic case for sustainable marine management and identify financing pathways aligned with national priorities.
Deliverable: A detailed cost-benefit analysis report evaluating proposed bioeconomic activities:



Financial feasibility assessments for:

New Marine Protected Areas (MPAs)
Carbon offset co-managed sites
Octopus closure sites
Seaweed farming plots
Pelagic anchovies (dagaa) initiatives
Alternative livelihoods (e.g., seaweed farming, eco-tourism)

Proposed green and blue finance instruments for funding:

Local tax mechanisms
Private investor partnerships
Climate finance instruments
Conservation trust funds
Payment for ecosystem services schemes




Policy guidance to support:

Blue economy growth and diversification
Biodiversity conservation and ecosystem restoration
Ecosystem resilience and climate adaptation
Alignment with national climate action plans and SDGs
Upscaling of successful initiatives













6. Interactive Digital Visualization Platform
Target Completion Date: 1 December 2025 - 15 April 2026
Lead: Masumbuko Semba and Emmanuel Mpina Objectives: Make complex spatial and economic data accessible and actionable for diverse stakeholders. Deliverable: An integrated digital visualization tool featuring:



Web Maps: Geospatial visualizations displaying:

Degraded hotspots in Tanzania requiring restoration
Marine biodiversity loss and gain spatial trends
State of Mkuranga and Mkoani districts showing physical features, ecological assets, and health indicators
Ecosystem valuation data and economic analysis results
Cost-benefit analysis for implementation of environmental and socioeconomic measures
Blue economy initiatives and innovations

District Focus: Detailed visualizations and statistics for Mkuranga and Mkoani:

Ecosystem status indicators
Biodiversity patterns and trends
Ecosystem service spatial distribution




Socioeconomic context and livelihood dependencies
Climate vulnerability assessments
Areas of potential marine resource-use conflicts
Community-priority conservation areas and fisheries closure areas
Blue carbon opportunities

title: About LMSP-Tanzania
text:
The Ad Hoc Group of Experts on Marine Spatial Planning (GEMSP - Tanzania) is an informal network of researchers, practitioners, and professionals dedicated to advancing Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) in Tanzania and the Western Indian Ocean region.
Since we are yet to be formalized as an official organization, we operate as an ad hoc group bringing together expertise from:

Academic institutions (universities and research centers)
Government agencies (fisheries, marine resources, environment)
Conservation organizations and NGOs
Community representatives and fishing associations
Development partners and international organizations



Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) is a place-based approach to ocean and coastal management that integrates the diverse needs and uses of marine spaces while ensuring sustainability. LMSP:

Centers on communities: Places local knowledge and community priorities at the heart of planning
Integrates multiple uses: Balances fishing, conservation, aquaculture, tourism, and other activities
Is science-informed: Uses the best available data and research to support decision-making
Connects local and national: Links community-level plans to national MSP frameworks and regional initiatives
Enhances stewardship: Builds local capacity and commitment to ocean care and management

title: About LMSP-Tanzania
text:
The Ad Hoc Group of Experts on Marine Spatial Planning (GEMSP - Tanzania) is an informal network of researchers, practitioners, and professionals dedicated to advancing Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) in Tanzania and the Western Indian Ocean region.
Since we are yet to be formalized as an official organization, we operate as an ad hoc group bringing together expertise from:

Academic institutions (universities and research centers)
Government agencies (fisheries, marine resources, environment)
Conservation organizations and NGOs
Community representatives and fishing associations
Development partners and international organizations



Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) is a place-based approach to ocean and coastal management that integrates the diverse needs and uses of marine spaces while ensuring sustainability. LMSP:

Centers on communities: Places local knowledge and community priorities at the heart of planning
Integrates multiple uses: Balances fishing, conservation, aquaculture, tourism, and other activities
Is science-informed: Uses the best available data and research to support decision-making
Connects local and national: Links community-level plans to national MSP frameworks and regional initiatives
Enhances stewardship: Builds local capacity and commitment to ocean care and management

title: About LMSP-Tanzania
text:
Our Vision
We envision coastal communities in Tanzania actively managing and stewarding their marine resources through collaborative, evidence-based Local Marine Spatial Planning that:

Supports sustainable livelihoods for fishers and coastal residents
Protects critical marine ecosystems and biodiversity
Strengthens governance and institutional coordination
Builds resilience to environmental and social changes
Contributes to the broader ocean economy and blue growth agenda

title: About LMSP-Tanzania
text:
What We Do

üî¨ Research & Knowledge Generation
Conduct and compile research on local marine systems, livelihoods, and management practices across Tanzania‚Äôs coastal regions.


ü§ù Facilitate Collaboration
Bring together diverse stakeholders‚Äîcommunities, government, NGOs, and private sector‚Äîto collaborate on marine spatial planning initiatives.


üìö Share Information & Best Practices
Maintain this website as a central repository of LMSP knowledge, data, case studies, and resources for practitioners across Tanzania and the WIO.


üåç Build Capacity
Support communities, government staff, and organizations in building skills and understanding for effective local marine spatial planning.


üîó Connect Local to National & Regional
Ensure local LMSP initiatives are aligned with Tanzania‚Äôs national MSP frameworks and broader Western Indian Ocean conservation and development goals.

title: About LMSP-Tanzania
text:
Objectives
The LMSP-Tanzania website and initiative focus on four core objectives:

Raise Awareness and Visibility of local MSPs in Tanzania
Increase Visibility of the team members‚Äô work on MSP and related fields
Mobilize Support from development partners and private sector
Be a Key Source on data and information for MSP

title: About LMSP-Tanzania
text:
Our Team
Our team brings diverse expertise across marine science, fisheries management, conservation, economics, data science, community engagement, and policy. Learn more about our team members and their areas of work.

title: About LMSP-Tanzania
text:
Guiding Principles

Community Stewardship: Coastal communities have the right and responsibility to steward their marine resources
Evidence-Based Decisions: Planning is grounded in scientific research and local ecological knowledge
Inclusivity: All stakeholders have a voice in planning processes
Sustainability: Economic, social, and environmental sustainability are integrated
Adaptive Management: Plans evolve as conditions and understanding change
Equity: Benefits are fairly distributed and vulnerable groups are protected
Collaboration: Success requires working across sectors and scales

Population & Demographics

Demographic profiles
Growth trends
Vulnerable populations

Tourism operators
Aquaculture practitioners
Other marine resource users

Employment patterns
Poverty indicators
Economic dependencies

3. Infrastructure & Use Data

Maritime Infrastructure

Ports and harbors
Landing sites
Shipping routes
Coastal development

Marine Activities

Fishing zones
Tourism areas
Aquaculture sites
Conservation areas

Conflict Areas

Overlapping uses
Access disputes
Management challenges


Access Infrastructure & Use Data



4. Environmental & Climate Data
Monitoring climate and environmental conditions:

Climate Indicators

Temperature trends
Storm frequency
Seasonal patterns

Community exposure
Adaptive capacity

title: Timeline & Milestones
text:
Week 1-2: Team formation and role assignments
Week 3-4: Stakeholder mapping and initial consultations
Week 5-12: Baseline data collection

Week 13-16: Community consultations and workshops

Week 25-28: Stakeholder feedback incorporation

Deliverable: Final MSP Plan, Implementation Strategy






Week 37-40: Monitoring system setup

Week 45-48: Performance analysis and reporting
Deliverable: Monitoring Report, Recommendations

title: FAQ - Marine Spatial Planning
text:
Marine Spatial Planning is a systematic process that evaluates the competing uses of the ocean and coastal areas and allocates space and resources to different uses in a way that balances economic, social, and environmental objectives.



Local Marine Spatial Planning focuses on implementing MSP principles at the local and community level, ensuring that coastal communities are central to the decision-making process and benefit directly from marine resource management.



Tanzania has extensive marine resources and a long coastline along the Indian Ocean. MSP helps to: - Protect marine biodiversity and ecosystems - Support sustainable fisheries - Enable blue economy growth - Reduce conflicts between different ocean users - Build climate resilience in coastal communities



LMSP is inclusive and welcomes participation from: - Government agencies - Fishing communities and fisher associations - Private sector (tourism, aquaculture, etc.) - NGOs and civil society organizations - Academic institutions - Development partners - Individual community members



You can reach out to us through our contact page or join our community surveys and polls to share your perspectives on local marine spatial planning priorities.



We provide: - Data and publications on MSP in Tanzania and the WIO region - MSP guidelines and best practices - Information on partner networks and opportunities - Community engagement platforms (polls and FAQs)



Visit our Resources section for access to MSP guidelines, publications, and links to partner organizations working on marine spatial planning in the Western Indian Ocean region.



MSP enables sustainable growth of blue economy activities by: - Creating predictable operating environments for businesses - Preventing conflicts between different ocean users - Protecting marine ecosystems that support fisheries and tourism - Facilitating investment in sustainable marine industries

title: Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) - Tanzania
text:
Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP): Enhancing community stewardship in spatial planning
This website is the hub for Local Marine Spatial Planning initiatives in Tanzania and the Western Indian Ocean. We are an Ad Hoc Group of Experts dedicated to promoting evidence-based, community-centered marine spatial planning across the country.






Important



Mission: To be the leading source and advocate for Local Marine Spatial Planning in Tanzania, strengthening community stewardship and sustainable ocean governance across the WIO region.

title: Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) - Tanzania
text:
Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP): Enhancing community stewardship in spatial planning
This website is the hub for Local Marine Spatial Planning initiatives in Tanzania and the Western Indian Ocean. We are an Ad Hoc Group of Experts dedicated to promoting evidence-based, community-centered marine spatial planning across the country.






Important



Mission: To be the leading source and advocate for Local Marine Spatial Planning in Tanzania, strengthening community stewardship and sustainable ocean governance across the WIO region.

title: Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) - Tanzania
text:
Our Objectives
The LMSP-Tanzania website serves four core objectives:


üåç Raise Awareness & Visibility
Increase awareness and visibility of local Marine Spatial Planning initiatives in Tanzania and showcase successful approaches to coastal communities and development partners.


üë• Increase Team Visibility
Highlight the expertise, research, and fieldwork of our team members working on MSP and related fields across the country.


ü§ù Mobilize Support
Draw partnerships and assignments from development partners and the private sector interested in supporting local Marine Spatial Planning efforts.


üìä Share Knowledge & Data
Be the key source for data, information, and best practices on MSP in Tanzania and the broader Western Indian Ocean region.

title: Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) - Tanzania
text:
Key Resources


üìñ Why LMSP Matters
Understand the importance of Local Marine Spatial Planning and how it connects to national MSP frameworks and Western Indian Ocean initiatives.


üìç LMSP Initiatives
Explore active Local MSP initiatives across Tanzania, their focus areas, and community engagement approaches.


üìä Data & Information
Access marine resources data, socioeconomic information, and spatial datasets for planning and analysis.


üë• Meet Our Team
Learn about the diverse expertise of our team members working across MSP, fisheries, conservation, and data science.

title: Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) - Tanzania
text:
Our Approach
LMSP-Tanzania operates on core principles:

Community-Centered: Prioritizing the knowledge and participation of coastal communities in planning processes
Evidence-Based: Grounded in scientific research and local ecological knowledge
Collaborative: Working across sectors with government, NGOs, private sector, and development partners
Scalable: Sharing lessons learned across Tanzania and the Western Indian Ocean region
Adaptive: Responsive to changing environmental and socioeconomic conditions

title: Local Marine Spatial Planning (LMSP) - Tanzania
text:
Connect With Us
Interested in Local MSP or want to collaborate? We‚Äôre looking for partnerships with development partners, research institutions, and community organizations.
Meet Our Team Get in Touch

LMSP-Tanzania | Ad Hoc Group of Experts on Marine Spatial Planning | Since 2026

title: Why LMSP
text:
Local Marine Spatial Planning bridges the gap between national policy frameworks and community-level implementation, ensuring that:

Communities are empowered to manage their own marine resources
Local knowledge is integrated with scientific expertise
Sustainable livelihoods are protected and enhanced
Bottom-up planning supports national conservation goals



Tanzania‚Äôs National MSP framework provides the overarching policy and strategic direction, while LMSP translates these national priorities into locally relevant and implementable actions.



National Level - Policy frameworks, national objectives, monitoring standards
Regional Level - Coordination between districts, resource management oversight
Local Level - Community engagement, livelihood considerations, site-specific planning





Policy Integration - LMSP initiatives must align with national MSP objectives while respecting local contexts
Data Contribution - Local initiatives feed data and insights to national monitoring systems
Stakeholder Coordination - Multi-level governance ensuring all voices are heard
Adaptive Management - National frameworks adapted based on local implementation experiences





‚úì National goals are grounded in local reality
‚úì Communities see direct benefits from planning processes
‚úì Cumulative impact assessment across the entire coastline
‚úì Resilience building at multiple governance levels
‚úì Sustainable resource management from local to national scale

For more information on national MSP frameworks, see our Resources section.

title: Community Polls - Marine Spatial Planning
text:
This page features regular community polls and surveys to gather input on local marine spatial planning priorities and preferences. Your feedback helps guide LMSP-Tanzania‚Äôs work and advocacy efforts.



What do you consider the highest priority for local marine spatial planning in your coastal community?

Protecting fish stocks and fisheries sustainability
Promoting sustainable tourism development
Protecting marine biodiversity and habitats
Supporting aquaculture and other marine industries
Ensuring community food security
Creating economic opportunities for youth

Status: Active | Responses: [Vote now]




Which stakeholders should be most involved in local MSP decisions in your community?

Government fisheries departments
Local fisher associations and communities
Private sector (tourism, aquaculture)
Environmental NGOs
Academic and research institutions
All equally represented

What is the biggest challenge to implementing local MSP in Tanzania?

Lack of awareness among communities
Limited technical capacity
Insufficient funding
Conflicting use demands
Weak coordination between agencies
Limited data on marine resources

title: Meet Our Team
text:
The LMSP-Tanzania team brings together diverse expertise in marine spatial planning, data management, policy development, and coastal governance.





Role: Project Lead & Biodiversity Assessment Coordinator
Affiliation: School of Aquatic Sciences and Fisheries Technology (SOAF)
Spatial ecologist with 15+ years of experience in coastal ecosystem assessment and geospatial analysis for marine conservation planning.
Dr.¬†Pamba leads the Marine Spatial Planning Initiative as institutional lead at SOAF. She specializes in spatial pattern analysis and biodiversity assessment, developing and applying advanced geospatial methods to characterize marine ecosystem diversity and conservation priorities. Her research contributes to evidence-based marine governance in the Indian Ocean region.
Key Focus Areas:

Spatial pattern analysis and ecosystem motifs
Landscape metrics and ecosystem signatures
Biodiversity assessment and conservation prioritization
Remote sensing and raster analysis
R programming for spatial data science
Marine spatial planning frameworks

Links:

Google Scholar
ORCID
SOAF Profile
Email: siajali.pamba@udsm.ac.tz







Role: Data Analyst, Graphics & Web Application Design Lead
Affiliation: Nelson Mandela African Institution of Science and Technology (NM-AIST)
Data scientist specializing in spatial and statistical analysis, interactive data visualization, and web application developement for complex spatial and ecological datasets.
Dr.¬†Semba leads data analysis, statistical modeling, and interactive graphics development for the Marine Spatial Planning Initiative. His expertise spans spatial and statistical analysis, automation of analytical workflows, and full-stack development of interactive visualization platforms using modern programming frameworks.
Key Focus Areas:

Data analysis and statistical modeling
Spatial analysis and geostatistics
Interactive graphics and data visualization
Web application design and development
Algorithm development and optimization
Workflow automation and report generation
Raster and vector spatial data analysis
Decision support system architecture

Links:

Google Scholar
ORCID
GitHub
NM-AIST Profile
Email: masumbuko.semba@nm-aist.ac.tz







Role: Policy Specialist & Ecosystem Services Coordinator
Affiliation: School of Aquatic Sciences and Fisheries Technology (SOAF)
Policy specialist bridging ecosystem science and governance, focused on translating spatial analysis into evidence-based coastal management policies.
Dr.¬†Julius develops policy recommendations and governance frameworks for sustainable marine resource management. He coordinates ecosystem services assessment and ensures that spatial planning outputs inform evidence-based coastal policy development at district and national levels. His work strengthens the link between scientific research and policy implementation.
Key Focus Areas:

Marine policy development and governance frameworks
Ecosystem services assessment and economic valuation
Fisheries policy and regulatory development
Social-ecological systems analysis
Livelihood impact assessment and community engagement
Policy translation and stakeholder communication

Links:

Google Scholar
ORCID
SOAF Profile
Email: julius.francis@udsm.ac.tz







Role: Bio-Economic Analysis & Visualization Lead
Affiliation: The Nature Conservancy, Tanzania
Digital innovation specialist and conservation economist creating interactive tools that transform complex spatial and economic data into actionable insights for decision-makers.
Emmanuel develops the digital visualization platform and conducts bio-economic cost-benefit analysis. He bridges technical analysis with stakeholder communication through interactive mapping tools and decision support systems. His expertise in data visualization enables diverse stakeholders to understand and act on complex marine spatial planning outcomes.
Key Focus Areas:

Bio-economic modeling and cost-benefit analysis
Interactive mapping and web-based visualization
Coastal community engagement and participatory planning
GIS and spatial data management

Links:

The Nature Conservancy - Tanzania
ORCID
Email: empina@tnc.org







Role: Field Operations & Logistics Coordinator
Affiliation: School of Aquatic Sciences and Fisheries Technology (SOAF)
Field operations specialist with expertise in survey coordination, equipment management, and community-based data collection for coastal research projects.
Mr.¬†Samson coordinates all field activities and logistics for the Marine Spatial Planning Initiative. He manages survey equipment, organizes fieldwork schedules, coordinates with local communities and fishing associations, and ensures smooth implementation of data collection protocols. His experience in coastal fieldwork and community engagement is essential for successful ground-truthing of satellite data and stakeholder involvement.
Key Focus Areas:

Field survey coordination and management
Community engagement and liaison
Equipment and logistics management
Data collection protocol implementation
Coastal fieldwork and site access coordination
Stakeholder communication and feedback collection

Links:

SOAF Profile
ORCID
Email: samson.job@udsm.ac.tz







Role: Socio-Economic Analysis & Livelihood Coordinator
Affiliation: School of Aquatic Sciences and Fisheries Technology (SOAF)
Socio-economic specialist focused on understanding fishing livelihoods, community needs, and social dimensions of marine spatial planning in coastal Tanzania.
Mr.¬†Gervas conducts socio-economic assessments and livelihood analysis for the communities in Mkoani and Mkuranga districts. He documents fishing practices, income sources, and community priorities, ensuring that marine spatial planning outcomes address local livelihood needs and support sustainable resource management. His work bridges ecological science and human wellbeing, making spatial plans locally relevant and socially acceptable.
Key Focus Areas:

Socio-economic assessment and livelihood analysis
Fishing community engagement and needs assessment
Livelihood impact assessment
Community priorities and resource use documentation
Social dimension integration in marine spatial planning
Participatory planning and community feedback

Links:

SOAF Profile
ORCID
Email: gervas.maro@udsm.ac.tz

Role: Bio-Economic Analysis & Visualization Lead
Affiliation: The Nature Conservancy, Tanzania
Digital innovation specialist and conservation economist creating interactive tools that transform complex spatial and economic data into actionable insights for decision-makers.
Emmanuel develops the digital visualization platform and conducts bio-economic cost-benefit analysis. He bridges technical analysis with stakeholder communication through interactive mapping tools and decision support systems. His expertise in data visualization enables diverse stakeholders to understand and act on complex marine spatial planning outcomes.
Key Focus Areas:

Bio-economic modeling and cost-benefit analysis
Interactive mapping and web-based visualization
Coastal community engagement and participatory planning
GIS and spatial data management

Links:

The Nature Conservancy - Tanzania
ORCID
Email: empina@tnc.org







Role: Field Operations & Logistics Coordinator
Affiliation: School of Aquatic Sciences and Fisheries Technology (SOAF)
Field operations specialist with expertise in survey coordination, equipment management, and community-based data collection for coastal research projects.
Mr.¬†Samson coordinates all field activities and logistics for the Marine Spatial Planning Initiative. He manages survey equipment, organizes fieldwork schedules, coordinates with local communities and fishing associations, and ensures smooth implementation of data collection protocols. His experience in coastal fieldwork and community engagement is essential for successful ground-truthing of satellite data and stakeholder involvement.
Key Focus Areas:

Field survey coordination and management
Community engagement and liaison
Equipment and logistics management
Data collection protocol implementation
Coastal fieldwork and site access coordination
Stakeholder communication and feedback collection

Links:

SOAF Profile
ORCID
Email: samson.job@udsm.ac.tz







Role: Socio-Economic Analysis & Livelihood Coordinator
Affiliation: School of Aquatic Sciences and Fisheries Technology (SOAF)
Socio-economic specialist focused on understanding fishing livelihoods, community needs, and social dimensions of marine spatial planning in coastal Tanzania.
Mr.¬†Gervas conducts socio-economic assessments and livelihood analysis for the communities in Mkoani and Mkuranga districts. He documents fishing practices, income sources, and community priorities, ensuring that marine spatial planning outcomes address local livelihood needs and support sustainable resource management. His work bridges ecological science and human wellbeing, making spatial plans locally relevant and socially acceptable.
Key Focus Areas:

Socio-economic assessment and livelihood analysis
Fishing community engagement and needs assessment
Livelihood impact assessment
Community priorities and resource use documentation
Social dimension integration in marine spatial planning
Participatory planning and community feedback

Links:

SOAF Profile
ORCID
Email: gervas.maro@udsm.ac.tz

title: Meet Our Team
text:
Our Experts

Julius Francis
Marine Spatial Planning Specialist
Julius leads the overall coordination of Local Marine Spatial Planning initiatives, bringing extensive experience in coastal zone management and community-based planning approaches.

Expertise: MSP strategy, stakeholder engagement, coastal governance
Focus: Overall LMSP coordination and implementation
Background: Years of experience in marine resource management




Siajali Pamba
Policy & Governance Expert
Siajali develops and advocates for policies that support LMSP implementation and alignment with national frameworks.

Expertise: Marine policy, regulatory frameworks, governance structures
Focus: Policy development and institutional coordination
Background: Policy analyst specializing in marine sectors




Masumbuko Semba
Data & Information Specialist
Masumbuko oversees the collection, management, and analysis of data supporting LMSP initiatives.

Expertise: Environmental data, GIS analysis, marine monitoring
Focus: Data infrastructure and information systems
Background: Environmental scientist and data management specialist




Emmanuel Mpina
Community Engagement Specialist
Emmanuel facilitates dialogue between government agencies, communities, and other stakeholders in LMSP processes.

Expertise: Community mobilization, participatory planning, livelihood assessments
Focus: Stakeholder engagement and social dimensions of MSP
Background: Community development professional




Samson Job
Fisheries & Livelihood Expert
Samson brings expertise in fisheries management and ensures LMSP initiatives support sustainable livelihoods.

Expertise: Fisheries science, livelihood sustainability, food security
Focus: Integration of fisheries perspectives in spatial planning
Background: Fisheries researcher and livelihood specialist




Gervas Maro
Environmental Conservation Specialist
Gervas ensures LMSP initiatives protect marine biodiversity and ecosystem services.

Expertise: Marine conservation, biodiversity monitoring, ecosystem assessment
Focus: Environmental sustainability and conservation objectives
Background: Marine ecologist and conservation professional




Rushingisha George
Data Analysis & Research Lead
Rushingisha conducts research and analysis to support evidence-based LMSP planning.

Expertise: Spatial analysis, research methodology, impact assessment
Focus: Research and analytical support for planning processes
Background: Research scientist and analyst




Idrissa Hamad
Regional Coordination Officer
Idrissa coordinates LMSP activities across different regions and ensures consistency in implementation.

Expertise: Regional coordination, multi-level governance, project management
Focus: Regional integration and coordination
Background: Governance and coordination specialist




John Mapunda
GIS & Spatial Data Specialist
John develops spatial databases and mapping tools to support LMSP visualization and analysis.

Expertise: GIS systems, spatial data infrastructure, cartography
Focus: Spatial data management and visualization
Background: GIS professional and mapping specialist




Limbu Mchele
Monitoring & Evaluation Expert
Limbu designs and implements monitoring systems to track LMSP progress and outcomes.

Expertise: M&E frameworks, performance indicators, adaptive management
Focus: Monitoring, evaluation, and adaptive management
Background: M&E specialist in marine sectors




Rose Mwaipopo
Gender & Social Inclusion Specialist
Rose ensures LMSP processes are inclusive and responsive to diverse social groups and gender considerations.

Expertise: Gender analysis, social inclusion, equity in resource management
Focus: Social and gender dimensions of LMSP
Background: Social scientist with focus on gender and inclusion




John Komakoma
Communications & Outreach Officer
John manages communication and outreach activities to build awareness and support for LMSP.

Expertise: Strategic communications, stakeholder outreach, knowledge dissemination
Focus: Advocacy, communication, and public engagement
Background: Communications professional
